g.text: What do we want to know?
s participation in the arts have on their learning, achievement
Who wants to know and why?
It is widely believed that participation in the arts has a range of benefits for young people.
makers wish to understand more about the nature and quantity of such benefits in
order to make better decisions about h
ow to make further investment in the arts.
participation in structured arts activities, participation in structured
There is promising, yet insufficient, evidence that participation in arts activities improves
studies conducted in North America, Europe or
Asia. Study populations included young people within the
the number of studies that addressed each of the specific sub
was small. Any consideration of policy responses will need to take into account a wide range
of other knowledge about policy and practice, other benefits that might be obtained from
articipation in arts, and the potential for other mechanisms to deliver these outcomes and
The size of the impacts identified could be interpreted as follows:
The participation of young people of secondary school age in structured arts activities
ould increase their academic attainment scores by 1% to 2%, on average, above that of
The participation of young people in structured arts activities could increase their
16% to 19%, on average, above that of non
The participation of young people in structured arts activities could increase their
transferable skills test scores by 10% to 17%, on average, above that of non
How did we get these results?
We carried out a systematic review of empirical research on engagement, impact and value in
culture and sport published in English since 1997.
identify studies and a combination of manual and automated screening was used to
select studies for inclusion based on pre
specified inclusion criteria. To be included in this in
depth review, studies had to focus on arts participation by young people, use
experimental research design and have quantitative outcome measures. Results from the
individual studies were transformed into a standardised effect size and, where appropriate,
analysis was used to combine the results from individual
interpretation of the results of the synthesis were derived using a standardised framework.
